title: Personalized Movie & TV Show Recommender
text:
In today’s crowded streaming industry, users face endless content options but often struggle to find shows and movies that truly match their preferences. This is where recommendation engines play a critical role in creating a more engaging, personalized viewing experience. My Personalized Movie & TV Show Recommender project tackles this challenge head-on, using advanced clustering techniques and similarity scoring to curate tailored suggestions for each user.


Imagine you’re on a streaming platform and have just finished a movie. What’s next? A good recommendation system is like a smart friend who knows your taste—offering suggestions that keep you watching, without the overwhelming feeling of endless scrolling. This personalization isn’t just a nice-to-have; it’s a strategic advantage for any streaming service. Personalized recommendations lead to higher viewer engagement, increased watch time, and ultimately, stronger brand loyalty. By using data to understand user preferences, streaming platforms can reduce churn rates and create a more satisfying viewer experience.



Creating a recommendation system that “gets” what users want requires a combination of data science techniques. Here’s the approach I used:

Data Collection & Preprocessing
The foundation of any data-driven project is clean, well-structured data. For this project, I consolidated a large dataset of movies and TV shows, including attributes like genre, type (movie or series), region, and IMDb ratings. I then applied feature encoding to turn these attributes into numerical values that machine learning algorithms can understand. Encoding genres, types, and regional data laid the groundwork for grouping similar items and calculating precise recommendations.
Clustering & Content Similarity
Next, I used clustering to organize the content into groups with similar attributes. By clustering movies and shows based on common characteristics, I created distinct “neighborhoods” of content. Within each cluster, I applied cosine similarity to assess how closely a movie or show aligns with a given user’s profile. This method is powerful because it ensures that users are recommended content not only based on popularity but also based on true similarity to their past preferences.
Precision & Personalization Through Cosine Similarity
Finally, I calculated cosine similarity scores within each cluster to generate a ranked list of recommendations. This approach enables a fine-grained level of personalization, as each recommendation aligns closely with user tastes. Unlike traditional popularity-based recommendations, this model tailors suggestions to individual viewing patterns, ensuring users receive content they’re more likely to enjoy.





Python for data manipulation, clustering, and implementing the recommendation logic.
Pandas & NumPy for managing and transforming large datasets.
Scikit-learn for clustering and calculating cosine similarity, helping to create groups of similar content.
Matplotlib & Seaborn to visualize user trends and analyze viewing preferences across clusters.




Working on this project was an incredible dive into the mechanics of personalized recommendation systems. Building a recommender system isn’t just about suggesting any content; it’s about delivering relevance. This project underscored how essential it is to understand user data, apply the right clustering techniques, and measure similarity accurately.
For streaming services, a system like this can significantly improve user satisfaction, reduce churn, and foster loyalty. In a data-driven world, building such tailored experiences doesn’t just enhance user engagement—it’s key to standing out in a competitive market.
This personalized movie and TV show recommender showcases the power of data-driven solutions to solve real-world problems, using advanced analytics and machine learning to deliver a truly engaging user experience.

title: Economic Correlations and Insights Analysis
text:
Understanding the economic and social well-being of countries requires a multifaceted approach. Factors such as GDP, corruption, cost of living, tourism, and unemployment rates all intertwine, shaping each nation’s unique economic landscape. This SQL-based Economic and Social Analysis of Countries project uses SQL as the core tool to dive into these connections, revealing insights that can inform economic policies and offer a data-backed understanding of how wealth, corruption, and other indicators influence global stability.


This project harnesses SQL to perform an in-depth exploration of economic indicators across multiple countries. By analyzing the relationships among factors such as GDP, corruption, tourism, and employment, this project aims to uncover patterns and correlations. The objective is to create a structured, data-driven approach to understand what drives economic health and stability around the world.




Correlation Analysis Between Corruption and GDP
One of the main objectives of this project is to quantify the relationship between corruption levels and GDP. Using SQL, I analyzed data across varying levels of corruption to assess its impact on economic growth. The SQL queries reveal how higher levels of corruption correlate with lower GDP, suggesting the negative economic consequences of corruption.
Examining Cost of Living’s Impact on Tourism and Employment
Cost of living is a crucial factor that affects not only residents but also the attractiveness of a country to international tourists. This analysis uses SQL to determine how cost of living influences tourism and employment rates, uncovering which countries see a tourism boost from affordability and how this impacts local job markets.
Building a Composite Index to Rank Economic Health
To provide a more comprehensive view, I created a composite index to rank countries based on overall economic health, incorporating factors like GDP, corruption, cost of living, and unemployment. SQL functions enabled grouping and ranking, allowing us to identify countries that score highly on economic health and those with room for improvement.




Using SQL’s grouping and filtering capabilities, the project also clusters countries into distinct performance categories. This clustering provides a comparative framework, making it easier to identify groups of countries with similar economic profiles. These clusters help highlight common challenges or strengths and offer insights into which factors are most influential for each cluster.




SQL: Central tool for querying, aggregating, and analyzing data to discover economic patterns.
Data Aggregation and Cleaning: Using SQL to prepare, clean, and handle missing or inconsistent data points.




This project extends beyond SQL skills to apply data analytics to real-world economic questions, providing several important takeaways:

Corruption is inversely related to economic growth, with countries facing high corruption generally experiencing lower GDP levels.
Cost of living plays a significant role in influencing both tourism and employment rates, positioning it as a critical metric for countries aiming to boost these sectors.
The composite index offers a streamlined method for comparing countries’ economic health, allowing for quick identification of top performers and those in need of improvement.

By focusing on SQL-based analysis, this project emphasizes the power of data-driven insights for understanding complex economic interactions. It serves as a valuable resource for policymakers, analysts, and researchers looking to make informed decisions that can contribute to both national and global economic resilience.

title: ABOUT
text:
I’m a Data Analyst with 4+ years of experience using data to support business and customer decision-making. I specialize in SQL, Python, and BI tools like Power BI and ThoughtSpot, with hands-on experience building dashboards, automating reports, and translating complex data into clear insights.
I’ve worked in client-facing and business analytics roles, where I partnered with stakeholders to improve metric visibility, reporting efficiency, and data accuracy. I’m currently pursuing an MS in Data Analytics Engineering at George Mason University and actively building projects in SQL, Power BI, and Python to deepen my analytics and machine learning skills.

title: Data Job Trends Analysis (2020- 2024)
text:
In a world where data drives decision-making across industries, the demand for data-related roles has been on a continuous rise. But how has the demand evolved globally, and what insights can we gain by analyzing these trends? The Data Job Trends Analysis Dashboard (2020-2024) is an interactive Power BI tool designed to answer precisely these questions. Spanning five years, this dashboard provides comprehensive insights into data job trends worldwide, helping professionals, recruiters, and industry experts make informed career and hiring decisions.


The primary objective of this project is to capture the changing landscape of data roles, including data analysts, data scientists, data engineers, and business analysts, from 2020 to 2024. By tracking job openings and market fluctuations, the dashboard enables a comparative analysis of how demand varies by country, offering a dynamic view of where opportunities in data are growing or waning.




Global Demand Analysis by Role and Country
The dashboard breaks down the demand for data roles across different countries, illustrating which regions have seen the most growth. Users can quickly spot trends in high-demand areas, understanding how countries like the United States, Germany, and India have evolved in terms of hiring for data roles. This feature aids recruiters and job seekers alike by providing a geographic view of the data job market.
Year-by-Year Market Fluctuations
With data spanning from 2020 to 2024, the dashboard highlights annual shifts in demand for data professionals. Users can analyze year-over-year changes in job postings, identifying patterns that correlate with global events, technological advancements, or economic conditions. This historical perspective offers valuable insights into the job market’s responsiveness to external factors, such as increased remote work, economic recovery efforts, and shifts in digital transformation priorities.
Country-Specific Trends and Market Insights
Beyond global trends, the dashboard allows users to zoom in on specific countries to see granular trends within their data job markets. This feature is particularly useful for professionals aiming to understand job demand in specific regions, recruiters refining their talent acquisition strategies, or career strategists guiding candidates based on local market conditions.





Power BI: Central tool for creating and designing an interactive dashboard, enabling clear, accessible data visualizations.
Data Aggregation and Cleaning: Data was prepared, transformed, and cleaned to ensure accuracy and consistency in trend analysis.
Excel: Used for data preparation, including data wrangling and initial preprocessing to optimize for Power BI integration.




The Data Job Trends Analysis Dashboard (2020-2024) provides several key insights, making it an invaluable resource for anyone connected to the data job market:

Rising Global Demand: Data roles have continued to grow worldwide, with countries like the United States and European nations showing steady increases in demand. This suggests a sustained need for data professionals across diverse industries.
Impact of Economic and Technological Shifts: Market fluctuations reflect responses to global trends, such as the adoption of remote work and increased investment in digital transformation. The dashboard showcases how these shifts influence demand for specific skills within data roles.
Regional Preferences and Opportunities: By pinpointing trends within each country, the dashboard highlights regional preferences for particular skill sets and data roles, helping professionals tailor their career paths accordingly.

For data analysts, recruiters, and career strategists, the Data Job Trends Analysis Dashboard serves as an essential tool to stay aligned with current job market needs, make data-driven career decisions, and forecast hiring demands in a rapidly evolving field.

title: Meta AD Analysis
text:
In the competitive landscape of digital marketing, data is the compass that guides every dollar spent. This project highlights a deep-dive analysis into a Meta Ad campaign with a significant $2.54M total budget , aimed at uncovering the drivers of high-value engagement and conversions.


Managing a large-scale advertising budget of $2.54M across multiple global regions often leads to “data fatigue,” where high-level metrics hide granular inefficiencies. Without a centralized view, it is difficult to determine exactly which demographic segments are driving the 2K purchases and whether the $50.72K average campaign spend is being allocated to the most active time windows.



I developed an interactive Meta AD Performance Dashboard that consolidates data from Facebook and Instagram to provide a single source of truth. By building dynamic filters for Campaign Name, Target Interest, and Month, the solution allows stakeholders to drill down from broad impressions to specific purchase behaviors in real-time.




Power BI: For data modeling, relationship mapping, and interactive visualization.
DAX (Data Analysis Expressions): To calculate critical performance ratios like CTR (11.79%), Engagement Rate (13.58%), and Purchase Rate (0.60%).





Demographic Sweet Spot: Engagement is most concentrated in the 20–30 age group, suggesting that creative messaging should remain tailored to a younger audience.
Gender Engagement: While the conversion rate is consistent across genders (0.05), the “All” gender category accounts for the largest share of engagement at 41.05%.
Prime Time Windows: Engagement peaks in the Afternoon (11,610) and stays strong through the Evening (11,574), identifying the optimal window for high-stakes ad delivery.
Format Reliability: Performance remains stable across Video, Image, and Stories, indicating that the current creative strategy is scalable across all Meta placements.
